text: Job’s Second Speech: A Response to Eliphaz
Then\f + \fr 6:1 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* Job answered and said,
“If only my vexation could be well weighed,
and my calamity could be lifted up together \add with it\add* in \add the\add* balances,
for then it would be heavier than the sand of the seas;
therefore my words have been rash,
for the arrows of Shaddai \add are\add* in me;
my spirit drinks their poison;
the terrors of God are arrayed against me.
Does \add the\add* wild ass bray over grass,
or \add the\add* ox bellow over its fodder?
Can tasteless \add food\add* be eaten without\f + \fr 6:6 \ft Hebrew “from without” \f* salt,
or is there taste in the white of a marshmallow plant?
⸤I refused⸥\f + \fr 6:7 \ft Literally “My soul/throat refuses” \f* to touch \add them\add*;
they \add are\add* like ⸤food that will make me ill⸥.\f + \fr 6:7 \ft Literally “the illness of my bread/food” \f*
“⸤O that⸥\f + \fr 6:8 \ft Literally “Who would give” \f* my request may come,
and \add that\add* God may grant my hope,
that\f + \fr 6:9 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* God would decide that\f + \fr 6:9 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* he would crush me,
\add that\add* he would let loose his hand and ⸤kill me⸥.\f + \fr 6:9 \ft Literally “he would cut me off” \f*
But\f + \fr 6:10 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* it will still be my consolation,
and I would recoil in ⸤unrelenting⸥\f + \fr 6:10 \ft Literally “he/it does not have compassion,” or “he/it does not have pity,” or “he/it does not spare” \f* pain,
for I have not denied \add the\add* words of \add the\add* Holy One.
What \add is\add* my strength, that I should wait?
And what \add is\add* my end, that ⸤I should hold out⸥?\f + \fr 6:11 \ft Literally “I should make my self long,” or “I should lengthen my self” \f*
Or \add is\add* my strength \add like\add* the strength of stones?
Or \add is\add* my flesh bronze?
⸤Indeed⸥,\f + \fr 6:13 \ft An interrogative marker plus “if” \f* my help is not in me,
and \add any\add* success is driven from me.
“Loyal love\f + \fr 6:14 \ft Or “Kindness” \f* \add should come\add* for the afflicted \add from\add* his friend,
even if\f + \fr 6:14 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* he forsakes the fear of Shaddai.
My companions are treacherous like a torrent-bed;
like a streambed of wadis\f + \fr 6:15 \ft A seasonal stream that is often dry \f* they flow away,
which are growing dark because of ice upon them,
it will pile up snow.
In time they dry up, they disappear;
when it \add is\add* hot, they vanish from their place.
The paths of their way wind \add around\add*;
they go up into the wasteland, and they perish.
The caravans of Tema looked;
the traveling merchants of Sheba hope for them.
They are disappointed, because they trusted;
they came ⸤here⸥\f + \fr 6:20 \ft Literally “up to it” \f* and they are confounded.
“For now you\f + \fr 6:21 \ft Plural throughout the rest of this chapter \f* have become ⸤such⸥;\f + \fr 6:21 \ft Literally “to it,” or “for it” \f*
you see terrors, and you fear.
Is it because I have said, ‘Give to me,’
or,\f + \fr 6:22 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* ‘Offer a bribe for me from your wealth’?
or,\f + \fr 6:23 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* ‘Save me from the foe’s hand,’
or,\f + \fr 6:23 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* ‘Ransom me from the tyrants’ hand’?
Teach me, and I myself\f + \fr 6:24 \ft Emphatic personal pronoun \f* will be silent;
and make me understand how I have gone astray.
How painful are ⸤upright words⸥!\f + \fr 6:25 \ft Literally “words of uprightness” \f*
But\f + \fr 6:25 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* what does ⸤your reproof⸥\f + \fr 6:25 \ft Literally “reproving from you” \f* reprove?
Do you intend to reprove \add my\add* words\f + \fr 6:26 \ft Or “Do you intend to reprove \fq with \ft words” \f*
and \add consider the\add* words of a desperate \add man\add* as wind?
Even over \add the\add* orphan you would cast the lot,
and you would bargain over your friend.
“⸤Therefore⸥\f + \fr 6:28 \ft Literally “And now,” or “And so then” \f* be prepared, turn to me,
and I surely will not lie to your face.\f + \fr 6:28 \ft Hebrew “faces” \f*
Please turn, let no injustice happen;
indeed,\f + \fr 6:29 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* turn, ⸤my righteousness is still intact⸥.\f + \fr 6:29 \ft Literally “still my righteousness \fq is \ft in it” \f*
Is there injustice on my tongue?
Or can my palate not discern calamity?\f + \fr 6:30 \ft Or “calamities” \f*
